results.headline: A Formidable Legacy and a Heavy Heart
results.summary_short: What happens when idealism becomes power? That question is the driving force of Jeremy Kagan’s inert yet strangely compelling film “Golda’s Balcony.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Golda's Balcony

results.headline: Rapper Meets Reggaetón (and Girl)
results.summary_short: There’s a lot going on under the surface of “Feel the Noise,” far more than its indefensibly generic title suggests.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Feel The Noise

results.headline: Suspicious and Curious Acts
results.summary_short: Somewhere between documentary and dramatization, fact and impression, “Strange Culture” molds one man’s tragedy into an engrossing narrative experiment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Strange Culture

results.headline: They Call Him the Fixer in a World That’s a Mess
results.summary_short: Dark in color, mood and outraged worldview, “Michael Clayton” is a film that speaks to the way we live now.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Michael Clayton

results.headline: Fighting for the Light
results.summary_short: The forces of Light and Dark are at it again in “The Seeker,” David L. Cunningham’s stilted fantasy about a pubescent lad charged with defeating evil.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Seeker

results.headline: A Child and Her Art, and the Bigger Picture
results.summary_short: “My Kid Could Paint That” explores a case in which the grown-up fascination with a child’s art appears to have spun out of control.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Kid Could Paint That

results.headline: Facing Dreams, Reality and the Music
results.summary_short: “The Good Night” might be described as a Dudley Moore movie without its namesake.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Good Night

results.headline: B. C. in 3-D
results.summary_short: The new National Geographic documentary “Sea Monsters” is a parade of special-effects money shots with academic credentials.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sea Monsters: A Prehistoric Adventure

results.headline: The Seven-Year Itch, Days After the Wedding
results.summary_short: If you haven’t seen the 1972 version of  “The Heartbreak Kid,” you’re missing a minor classic. If you haven’t seen Peter and Bobby Farrelly’s new version, I’m jealous.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Heartbreak Kid

results.headline: Parody and Tight Jumpsuits
results.summary_short: A faux documentary grounded in ethnicity and mired in absurdity, “Finishing the Game” is a terrific idea still waiting to be fashioned into a real movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Finishing the Game

results.headline: Meeting Mr. Wrong
results.summary_short: If “Broken,” directed by Alan White, defies basic credibility, it is at least well acted.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Broken

results.headline: Bible Lesson in Gay Rights
results.summary_short: “For the Bible Tells Me So” is, strictly speaking, an educational film, but there is no denying that it fills a need.
results.display_title: For The Bible Tells Me So

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For The Bible Tells Me So

results.headline: Lost in Utah
results.summary_short: “Desert Bayou” recounts the experiences of African-American survivors of Hurricane Katrina who were evacuated to Utah.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Desert Bayou

results.headline: A Neighbor’s-Eye View of Deep Depravity
results.summary_short: If you’re going to make a film as repellent as “Jack Ketchum’s the Girl Next Door,” you had better make sure that your redeeming reasons for doing so are crystal clear.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl Next Door

results.headline: Abortion as a Front Line in the Culture Wars
results.summary_short: One lesson of “Lake of Fire” is the galvanizing power of the visual image. Sometimes a picture is worth a thousand words, and sometimes pictures are not enough.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lake of Fire

results.headline: The Voice of a Rock Star in His Twilight
results.summary_short: It’s hard to know who the audience might be for the documentary oddity “Kurt Cobain About a Son,” but I bet its subject would have hated it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kurt Cobain About A Son

results.headline: Life Lessons in a Global Marketplace
results.summary_short: “Outsourced,” in which a Seattle call center manager is fired and then dispatched to India as a consultant to train his own replacement, is a wonderful surprise.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Outsourced

results.headline: Paying the Price
results.summary_short: An eagerly prurient dip into the sex-trafficking trough, “Trade” teeters between earnest exposé and salacious melodrama.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trade

results.headline: Sugar Cane’s Bitter Harvest in the Dominican Republic
results.summary_short: “The Price of Sugar” is a muckraking documentary about Haitians lured into a form of indentured servitude on sugar plantations in the Dominican Republic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Price of Sugar

results.headline: A Cad and a Femme Fatale Simmer
results.summary_short: “Lust, Caution” is a sleepy, musty period drama about wartime maneuvers and bedroom calisthenics, and the misguided use of a solid director.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lust, Caution
